title: coronavirus-lockdown-bin-collections-continue-libraries-closed
story: New restrictions impacting on businesses and ious services across the country were introduced by Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on Monday.But East Lothian Council has moved to assure people that bin collections will continue "as scheduled" while recycling centres "remain open for essential visits where required".However, libraries will not open in lockdown, with click and collect services operating at Dunbar, Haddington, Musselburgh and North Berwick libraries.A council spokesperson said: "Users who have signed up can browse the collection on our website."These arrangements may be subject to change."

title: coronavirus-lockdown-no-plan-resilience-groups-return
story: Hundreds of volunteers stepped forward in March to help more than a dozen voluntary groups in towns and villages across the county.Volunteers did everything from collecting shopping and prescriptions to dog walking and providing someone to talk to for vulnerable members of the community.Members of the community also gave up their time for a number of months to produce face masks, scrubs and shields for key workers.New lockdown restrictions were introduced on Monday by Scotlandrsquos First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.Representatives of East Lothian Council met the following day to discussthere was a role for the community groups. However, it is understood that community groups will not step forward at the moment.Chris McEwan, chairman of Haddingtonrsquos community council, was heavily involved in the resilience efforts in the town last year.He said the decision on whether the resilience groups couldlay with the local authority but stressed volunteers had already been in touch to seetheir help was required.Mr McEwan said the group would ldquospring into actionrequired and added: ldquoThe resilience team will be there ready. We have had discussions with a couple of volunteers but officially the council has to activate the group.It was a similar story in Dunbar, where community volunteers were on hand to help with a number of tasks, including providing hot meals to vulnerable people and those shielding.Disused laptops and tablets were also refurbished and passed on to students who were unable to attend school.George Robertson headed up Dunbarrsquos community resilience team, which was split into nine areas covering both the town and neighbouring West Barns.The community councillor and chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership said he was waiting on confirmation from East Lothian Council as to whether they would need to reconvene, something also echoed in North Berwick.Judy Lockhart, chairman of North Berwick Community Council , said it too was waiting on authorisation from the council.She added: ldquoThere are concerns about the pressure that leading the resilience had on volunteers last time. NBCC is run completely by volunteers, many of whom also have full-time jobs.ldquoWe had y discussions with ELC last time round and provided them a report on all we had done.ldquoWe hope thatresilience is required again, there will be far more support and our level of involvement will be lessened. We will await an update.At the grouprsquos virtual meeting on Tuesday, the wardrsquos new Connected Communities manager Doug Haig reminded members that the community centre had food and essential household items available to those finding themselves in dficult circumstances.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe support provided by our wonderful local resilience groups to the most vulnerable in our communities during the first lockdown early in  cannot be underestimated. They were a leline to many."During this current temporary lockdown, the council has decided that at the moment, it is not necessary to reinstate these groups."The current advice is for those on the shielding list to work from home where possible and, where not possible, to stay away from the workplace. They are not being asked to undertake full shielding again, but to pay particular attention to national advice on avoiding infection."For that reason, and the fact there is more support available now than in March last year, for example access to priority supermarket delivery slots and support grants for self-isolation, we are not asking resilience groups to operate again."We will continue to monitor the situation and,there is an increase in demand for support, we will respond to that in the most appropriate way."We will also be issuing a reminder of the support available via our website, social media channels, our local media partners and via community councils.

title: chance-say-proposed-crematorium-old-craighall
story: Westerleigh Group wants to build the facility off the A, on the opposite side of the carriageway from the Musselburgh Service Area, close to the junction of the A with the City of Edinburgh Bypass at Old Craighall.The -acre site ndash sandwiched between the eastbound carriageway of the Bypass and westbound carriageway of the A ndash would include a chapel, parking and a landscaped garden of remembrance. It is expected to accommodate an average of five or six services a day.A proposal of application notice was submitted to East Lothian Council last November.The next stage of the process is public consultation and this will take place next Thursday .Due to the Covid- pandemic, the consultation will take place online, -pm at holderplanningRepresentatives from the Westerleigh Group will be present to answer questions about the development. Visitors to the virtual consultation will also be able to submit feedback afterwards using the online form.Roger Mclaughlan, chief executive officer of Westerleigh Group, said: ldquoThere is a pressing need for a new crematorium to serve East Lothian this area already has a large population base which is going to grow further in the coming years, with some signicant new housing developments being planned.ldquoOur proposed new crematorium will also serve the wider Edinburgh City region.ldquoWe pride ourselves on creating and maintaining crematoria which are attractive places for remembrance and reflection, and which are true assets to their local communities.ldquoThe views of local people are very important to us as we always aim to enjoy very positive relationships with the communities around all our sites.ldquoThis facility will create direct employment and indirect employment through complementary services.

title: third-covid-19-vaccine-approved-uk-use
story: The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency has approved the Moderna coronavirus vaccine, the Department for Health has announced.The new vaccine works in a similar way to the Pfizer vaccine that is already being offered by the NHS.The Moderna vaccine requires temperatures of around -C, similar to a normal freezer, making it easier to store and distribute.The UK Government has ordered  million doses of the Moderna jab, but supplies will not delivered until the spring.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: ldquoThis is further great news and another weapon in our arsenal to tame this awful disease.ldquoWe have already vaccinated nearly . million people across the UK and Modernarsquos vaccine will allow us to accelerate our vaccination programme even further once doses become available from the spring.ldquoWhile we immunise those most at risk from Covid, I urge everyone to continue following the rules to keep cases low to protect our loved ones.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said approval of the Moderna vaccine was ldquogreat news.He tweeted: ldquoVaccination is obviously now the huge national priority. Given the intense pressure the NHS is under itrsquos vital NHS staff on frontline are vaccinated urgently.Great news.Vaccination is obviously now the huge national priority. Given the intense pressure the NHS is under itrsquos vital NHS staff on frontline are vaccinated urgently. https:t.co RKQNiVaccines are being offered to the most vulnerable members of society first.The Governmentrsquos nine high priority groups covers around  million people in the UK.

title: blindwells-developers-ask-delay-road-improvements-first-235-families-move
story: Hargreaves Services Ltd, which is developing the new Blindwells settlement, has asked planners to change a condition demanding access roads from the A into the new housing are upgraded before any residents move in.Instead, it says that a new study has shown that up to  houses could be occupied before any work is needed to improve the major access routes.Concern about the impact of the new town, which will be accessed off the Bankton interchange on the A, have been raised repeatedly by concerned members of the local community as the project progresses.At a recent virtual public consultation on changes to the new town layout, representatives of the developers heard concerns about the impact of traffic generated by the new town on the road network.The first residents of Blindwells, which will eventually see an initial population of ,, are expected to move in this September.East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan includes the initial delivery of Blindwells with a town centre, housing and new primary school.It also has a larger area of land to the east of the town ndash which sits between Prestonpans and Tranent ndashwhich has been dubbed Greater Blindwells for future expansion.Current education plans for children and young people moving into Blindwells will see primary-school children bussed to classes at neighbouring Cockenzie Primary School until completion of the new primary school, now due to be delivered on site for school session  .Secondary-school pupils will travel to Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.Concerns about the travel plans for school pupils, impact of the new town on the existing junctions on and off the A, and environmental impact were all raised by members of the public during the virtual consultation last month.East Lothian planners initially approved the building of the first phase of houses with a condition which requires upgrades to the Bankton interchange, including traffic control signals at the roundabouts and additional upgrades to the slip roads.However, in an application to be heard by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee next week, Hargreaves argues that a transport survey carried out for it shows that the initial  houses will have no ldquomaterial impact ndash a claim it says is accepted by Transport Scotland and the council.Hargreaves asks the committee to amend the condition to state that the upgrade work only needs to be carried out ldquoprior to the occupation of the th residential unit hereby approved.It currently states that the work must be carried out ldquoprior to the occupation of any of the approved development.The report to committee from planning officers recommends the change to the condition is approved.

title: an-early-april-fool-reaction-musselburgh-lagoons-formula-1-race-track-plan
story: Councillor Andy Forrest, a ward member for Musselburgh and Depute Provost of East Lothian, said on Twitter: "Next years F calendar: Monza, Monaco, Musselburgh."Thought I had slept through the first three months of  when I saw this, has to be an early April Fool."The proposal for an international race track at Musselburgh Lagoons is being put forward by The Sunbeam Trust, set up by retired Peebles businessman Bob Jamieson.The proposal would see other sports facilities based at the site, including an ice rink, gym and speedway venue however, the main focus would be a race track.Councillor John Williamson, ward member, said: "My understanding is that no formal planning application has been submitted. It appears to be a purely speculative proposal as the land in question belongs to the Musselburgh Common Good Fund."It is a much used and loved public open space, watersports area on the pond and nature reserve."Councillor Stuart Currie, ward member, said: "This is a speculative proposal that has not been encouraged or asked for."In my view, the lagoons area is an exceptional area that is enjoyed by so many in our town, particularly as a place to walk during the current pandemic."II do not welcome this proposal and will represent my constituents to oppose it in any way I can should it come forward."Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: "I would like to make it clear that I will not be supportive of this proposal."This proposal would remove a beloved nature area in the constituency and would be detrimental to the wildle in the area."I know that many constituents will be very dismayed when they hear of these proposals and will be devastated at the thought of losing this spot for birdwatchers, dog walkers and those who enjoy the outdoors."The Friends of Musselburgh Links said on Twitter: "We have contacted the head of planning at the council to express our concern and seek assurances but we hope this silly idea never even gets submitted."An online campaign to Say NO to detrimental developments at Musselburgh Lagoons, launched in the wake of the race track plan, has already collected more than , signatures.They raised road traffic concerns with the "influx" of people coming to the area.Members of the public have also taken to social media to air their views about the plan.Comments included:

title: chameleon-lady-release-inspired-coronavirus-lockdown
story: Called Lucky One, the song is very personal to drummer guitarist Robbie Hutchison, a former Loretto School pupil, as it conveys his emotions over the past year.The single projects his dficulties in being isolated on his own for the duration of the lockdown whilst also struggling to come to terms with the complicated relationships within his personal le.Robbie plays in the band along with his sister Caitlin, who also went to Loretto, and their dad Kenny who taught music at Loretto for  years, his nephew Michael Fitzpatrick, and Cameron Middlemass and his brother Tom, both former Loretto pupils.In a statement, the band, which plays a blend of folk, rock and pop, said: ldquoThese emotions are conveyed through a fictional story in the song. Due to the strong family ties in the band, it was natural to share and convey these emotions and made it easier when adding parts and ideas to Robbiersquos already personal track. All of this has allowed us to write, record and produce a song that we are very proud of and incredibly excited to share.Tom, guitarist and drummer, Cameron, lead vocalist, and Robbie first started making music together in  while still at school. title: pictures-north-berwick-residents-street-window-advent-calendar
story: Neighbours in Victoria Road and the harbour area set up a WhatsApp group, with each house allocated a number between one and , representing the  days of advent between December  and December .Each homeowner made and presented a display of their own interpretation of what an advent calendar window might consist of.A similar initiative has been produced by residents in Stair Park, found near North Berwick High and Law Primary Schools.The idea for Victoria Road came from a child who lives on the street, called Alva, who saw images of witches being displayed in the streetrsquos windows during Halloween and asked her mumthe same could be done for Christmas.The mother spoke to Hilary Smith, who also lives on the street and is chair of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, and askedthis is something that could be done.Hilary then posted a letter through her neighboursrsquo doors askingthey would be interested in taking part, with all showing interest.They soon got to work and created their displays using items that they already had at home, with discussions only taking place via WhatsApp and no prior meetings or planning taking place.Hilary said: ldquoThat was part of it, people had to use stuff they already had at home. I didnrsquot want to put pressure on anyone and feel like they had to buy something, it was more about each person and what they had.ldquoWe canrsquot do our usual stuff this Christmas, we canrsquot do much and canrsquot go very far so itrsquos been a nice way of bringing people together.ldquoEveryone has really bought into it and really embraced this. People who donrsquot usually interact are now all talking on the WhatsApp group and the displays are a topic of conversation.ldquoItrsquos not been competitive, everyone has been really enjoying it and itrsquos nice that it has brought people together.ldquoIt started off as a way for us to do something nice for ourselves but now more has come from it, which is great.A range of window displays have been produced, from festive scenes to some inspired by famous paintings, with something available for both adults and children.Images of each window were posted during advent on local art group pARTicpatersquos Instagram page, allowing the efforts to be shared with a wider audience.All of the windows have been very well received by people of all ages across the town with residents hearing many stopping outside and discussing their display.Today , all of the residents will be putting candles and or lights by their front doors to light up the street, as a way of marking the th day of advent that usually sees advent calendars have their biggest gt or biggest chocolate.It is not known how long each display will be up for, with Hilary suggesting that some may be taken down with the rest of the Christmas decorations.

title: ten-best-series-stream-lockdown
story: Butyou have exhausted the extensive list of shows to watch on ious streaming s you may be looking for a new series to binge.Luckily there are plenty of treats to tempt even the most discerning viewer across streaming s such as Netflix, Amazon, Now TV and BBC iPlayer.Here are some of the best.Itsworth pointing out that some of these shows are not suitable for children!Bridgerton ndash NetflixIf you have not yet delved into the world of Bridgertonrsquos raunchy Regency London, with a young, erse and gorgeous cast, what have you been waiting for Starring Phoebe Dynevorand Rege-Jean Page, and voiced by Dame Julie Andrews, each episode is a delicious confection.The Wilds ndash Amazon Prime VideoTeenage girls meet Lord Of The Flies in this series about young people from radically dferent backgrounds who find themselves stranded on a remote island.However, they are unaware they have just become the subjects of an elaborate social experiment.The Mandalorian ndash Disney+Hailed title: east-lothians-football-clubs-see-remaining-january-matches-postponed
story: Concerns about the ldquoescalating coronavirus situation have seen football from below the Scottish Professional Football LeagueChampionship down, including the East of Scotland Football League , postponed for the rest of January.The Scottish Football Associationboard met on Sunday to discuss the pandemic "and its impact on the national game at all levels".A statement on the governing bodys website said: ldquoFollowing a meeting between the Scottish FA and the Minister for Public Health Sport and Wellbeing, both parties have agreed to impose a temporary suspension of all football beneath the Scottish Professional Football League Championship, encompassing all predominantly part-time tiers of the Scottish professional pyramid, from midnight tonight.ldquoThe impacted leagues are: SPFL League One, SPFL League Two, Scottish Womenrsquos Football Premier Leagues   , Highland League, Lowland League, East, West  South of Scotland Leagues, Scottish Junior FA Leagues and the North Caledonian League.Tranent Juniors were the only East Lothian team in action over the weekend as their Scottish Cup adventure came to an end at East Fe.The Belters, who sit top of the EOSFL Premier Division, were due to face Dundonald Bluebell this weekend but no games will now take place until February  at the earliest.Fellow Premier Division sides Musselburgh Athletic and Dunbar United were due to face Sauchie and Crossgates respectively this weekend, while Ormiston were due to welcome Kirkcaldy and Dysart, and Haddington Athletic were facing St Andrews in the First Division Conference A.Preston Athletic were not scheduled to have a game this weekend.However, those games will all now need to be rescheduled.Rod Petrie, Scottish FA president, said: ldquoThe Scottish FA is well aware of the efforts all clubs take to comply with the exacting protocols that were conditional on elite football being given an exemption to continue amid the pandemic.ldquoNonetheless, the continuation of football at all levels has weighed increasingly heavy on me as president, my colleagues on the board and the joint response group as we have watched the new strain of the virus spread rapidly.ldquoWhile national sport has been afforded the privilege of elite sporting exemption, the risk of mass transportation of untested, largely part-time players is something that cannot be sustained as the cases continue to rise and available hospital beds become increasingly scarce.ldquoAfter discussions with the SPFL, the Premiership and Championship will continue on the proviso that both adhere to the existing testing regime.ldquoThe vast majority of teams in those isions are full-time professional clubs and so the risk of transmission remains manageably low.ldquoThe cost implications to lower-ision clubs was one factor but so too the realisation that many ndash with some notable exceptions ndash consist of part-time players who are either prevented from working due to the virus or have to work.ldquoIn either case, the risk is currently too great amid the developing nationwide spread of the virus.

title: covid-vaccine-scotland-centres-roll-oxford-jab
story: The first dose has been rolled out in GP practices and community vaccination centres after already beengiven in primary care settings in NHS Tayside, Lothian, Orkney and Highland.Scots will be told by letter or phone call when it is their turn to be vaccinated.Officials are urging people to take up the offer, and not to contact their GP.The first priority group for the vaccine is residents in a care home for older adults and their carers, people aged  or over and frontline health and social care workers.The order in which people will be offered the vaccine is based on advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.The JCVI list is as follows:The Scottish Government have published a full list of locations throughout Scotland where the vaccine will be administered.We have pulled these areas into a map, so that you can find your nearest centre.It is important to note that you should not go to one of these centres without an appointment - your health board will be in touch via phone call or letter when it is time to be vaccinated.Some locations on this list are not available due to technical reasons. Please check your appointment letter for your centre details.Yes. With much of Scotland now in level four lockdown restrictions, we are being advised to only leave home when necessary. But it has been confirmed that gettingthe COVID- vaccine is a permissible reason to leave the home.On Sunday, health secretary Jeane Freeman said: ldquoThe delivery of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine is a major development for the biggest vaccination programme we have ever delivered. I would like to thank everyone involved for their continued efforts to ensure the pace of the programme continues. Next week I will update parliament with further logistical detail of the vaccination programme.ldquoWe have over , vaccination sites, including over  GP practices with a growing core of over  trainedvaccinators to deliver the vaccine. When it is your turn to be vaccinated you will be contacted by your local health board and I urge you to please take up the offer. Please do not contact your GP but wait for your letter or phone call. And please remember that when the time comes for your second dose, it is crucial you get it as this is vital for longer term protection and to complete the course.ldquoAs ever, we are dependent on the vaccine supply and we continue to explore all possible options to speed up the delivery of all vaccine and bring forward timescales where possible.ldquoThis work, alongside our expanded testing strategy, rigorously complying with restrictions where we live and adhering to the public health guidance, is essential to protect those most at risk and minimise further impact on the NHS and social care services.

title: formula-1-track-musselburgh-lagoons-thousands-oppose-plans-petition
story: Anger over the proposal by a retired businessman for Musselburgh Lagoons has seen more than , people object.However, in a war of words on social media, businessman Bob Jamieson has hit back, accusing those supporting the wildle sanctuary of putting the welfare of ldquocannibal seagulls ahead of the local economy.Citing news reports from  in which it was claimed seagulls were eating other birds, small creatures and each other as climate change affected their behaviour, he told protestors: ldquoIf East Lothian wants cannibal seagulls rather than new jobs, tourism and local economic benefitshellip that is your choice.The proposal foran international race track at the lagoons is being put forward by The Sunbeam Trust, set up by Mr Jamieson.He called on East Lothian Council to consider his proposal instead of continuing with plans to turn the lagoons into a wildle haven.But his proposal has sparked a furious reaction, with thousands signing a petition demanding the lagoons be protected from ldquodetrimental developments in the wake of the plans.The Scottish Greens also hit back at the plans as ldquohare-brained.Laura Moodie, Scottish Green Party candidate for South Scotland region, said: ldquoThis is a horrendous proposition and deserves to be opposed every step of the way.ldquoThe developerrsquos claim that the lagoonrsquos wildle is a lsquowasted opportunityrsquo is an insult to the hundreds of people who use the area for recreation every day.ldquoRather than hear about hare-brained schemes like this, what we need to do is ensure that the proposals for the wider redevelopment of the Cockenzie Power Station area are sustainable and balance the creation of jobs with improving the natural environment of this beautul coastline.The ash lagoons were created during the years of operation of Cockenzie Power Station.Waste ash from the energy plant was transported via pipes to the lagoons, which are located on the seaward side of Musselburgh Racecourse.A large part of the -hectare ash lagoons has already been reclaimed, grassed and transferred to East Lothian Council ownership, providing a habitat for wildle, with the last two lagoons also earmarked for the haven.However, Mr Jamieson has describedthe wildle proposals as a ldquowasted opportunity and is urging council bosses to look again at the trustrsquos race track proposal.He said: ldquoIt is scandalous that this valuable site will not generate any local income from birdwatchers, butterflies and seagulls.He reacted to the petition, which has , signatures, by pointing to the impact seagulls ndash which he said would be attracted to the site by picnickers ndash would have on wildle.East Lothian Council stressed that no formal planning application for the race track had been submitted ldquoas yet.A spokesperson said: ldquoAny formal planning application submitted to the council for consideration would, of course, be subject to the usual procedures, with members of the public having the opportunity to comment.ldquoNo such planning application has yet been submitted to the council.

title: over-80s-start-receiving-covid-vaccine-east-lothian
story: At Riverside Medical practice, Musselburgh, appointments had already been booked for the first of its over-s to come in for the vaccine today.Among them was Musselburgh grandmother Anna Boyle, , who received the vaccine from lead nurse Diane Fyffe.Anna said:"Ive always had vaccines. I have great faith in this vaccine and think its very worthwhile."Riverside is set to roll out the vaccine to up to  patients as the first phase of the programmesees over-s given priority appointments.GP practices across the county received delivery of the vaccine over the weekend.At the Harbours Practice, Cockenzie, delighted staff took to Twitter to announce their delivery had arrived as they prepared to welcome patients to the surgery.The Riverside - the largest GP practice in East Lothian - recived an initial allocation of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine which was approved for use in January by the UKrsquos Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agencyafter an independent review process.In line with new guidance set out by the UK Government and NHS Boards one shot will be given initially, with a second dose after  weeks - an approach which will maximise the number of people with some protection at a time when infection rates have increased.Housebound patients, aged  and over, will be offered vaccination by local health board vaccination teams and will be contacted directly."Wersquore delighted to start playing our part in this crucial national Covid- vaccination programme," said Dr Joanna Stenke, GP partner at the Riverside.She explained: "By being vaccinated we can all play our part in ending this pandemic, and look forward to theof parts of le we miss so much, such as spending time with family and friends."I wholeheartedly recommend that everyone eligible should have the vaccine. I had my first dose as it was offered to frontline health workers and know my family will be lining up to do the same as soon as theyrsquore eligible."GPs across the country have been asked by the Government to offer the vaccine to those aged  and over initially, in line with the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrsquos list of the most at-risk groups. Therersquos no need to contact the surgery: this first group of patients ndash and every group GPs are asked to offer the vaccine to thereafter ndash will get a phone call or letter with all the details they need.She said: "While itrsquos great news that this first group of patients are getting the vaccine, itrsquos important that we all continue to follow the national and local guidance to prevent transmission of the virus, even after vaccination. Itrsquos only when a good number of us have been vaccinated that wersquoll start to see the light at the end of the tunnel."For more information about Covid- vaccines, including who will be offered vaccination and when, visit www.nhsinform.scot.

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-five-rules-made-tougher
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is today meeting with Cabinet to discuss the situation across the country, with any further changes being considered then.It comes as Deputy First Minister John Swinney said he could not rule out making further changes to current lockdown restrictions - and that the rules currently in place could be extended.He saidthere is "every likelihood" of stricter rules"human interaction" is not reduced.So what could be changed The First Minister has hinted earlier this week that fast food takeaways ndash including big name chains ndash may have to close.Itrsquos thought they would instead rely on deliveries, much like in the early lockdown back in March.Ms Sturgeon also suggested that shops currently operating a Click and Collect system would have to halt doing so under changes to the rules.She said: ldquoThe kind of issues we will be looking at ndash do we have to tighten up to reduce the number of people who are moving around any further ldquoI talked last week about perhaps reducing click and collect, essential retail only, to maybe looking at further restrictions on takeaways, she said."Weve not reached decisions on these things yet, but these are the kinds of things well be considering at our meeting and then Ill set out any decisions that we reach in the normal way."Discussions are being raised south of the Border around potential new rules around face coverings.Itrsquos thought there, coverings may become mandatory in some outdoor settings ndash such as supermarket queues ndash and businesses could be asked to tighten up their rules around office workers wearing masks while at work.When previously asked about the wearing of coverings outdoors, Ms Sturgeon said ldquoI am not going to rule anything out.ldquoBut in a pandemic we are trying to get everything we can to get transmission under control. Low impact is maybe not as good as high impact but itrsquos better than no impact.ldquoSo anything that we might think can make a contribution to this massive effort to keep the virus under control, we will consider.One other possible area being looked at is the levels of interaction during exercise outdoors.During the first lockdown, people in Scotland were limited to one portion of outdoor daily activity.Speaking during the Scottish Governmentscoronavirusbriefing, Ms Sturgeon said: "When we mean go out for essential exercise, thats what we mean ndash to get exercise, to get some fresh air."Weve not put limits on that like we did in the first lockdown."What we dont mean by essential exercise is going for a day trip with other people to the beach or to a park."I know that sounds harsh but it is really important right now that all of us stay at home as much as we possibly can.And Scotlandrsquos Chief Medical Officer said people should not be meeting outside to have coffees on park benches.He said: "Go outside to take exercise."Its important that were still participating in physical activities. Its good for us both physically and mentally."But dont be going outside to meet each other, have a cup of coffee, sit on a park bench, things like that."Youre only putting yourself at risk and the other person at risk as well.Looking south of the Border, police in England will now be quicker to issue pound fines to people breaking lockdown restrictions.New police guidance there, published on January , says the goal for police should be to ldquoencourage voluntary compliance, but that enforcement can be applied ldquowithout repeated attempts to encourage people to comply with the law.This new move could spark a similar response in Scotland and comes as four people were arrested after protesters clashed with police at an anti-lockdown demonstration.A small crowd gathered at Holyrood at around pm on Monday to take part in the Scotland Against Lockdown event.Community liaison officers warned those who were in attendance that they would face a finethey stay at the location, however many refused to leave.In a statement, a Police Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoWe can confirm that four people were arrested and charged in connection with alleged breaches of coronavirus regulations at a planned demonstration at the Scottish Parliament today.ldquoAll are due to appear in Edinburgh Sherf Court in due course.ldquoOne other person was charged with police obstruction and will be the subject of a report to the Procurator Fiscal.ldquoTwo other people were given fixed penalty notices for breaching coronavirus regulations.Superintendent David Robertson, from Edinburgh Police Division, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government regulations are clear that no marches or parades are allowed due to the restrictions in place.ldquoOfficers were on hand to engage with those who wanted to take part, explain the restrictions and used enforcement as a last resort where it was required.

title: river-called-time-ambitious-thought-provoking-sometimes-baffling-book
story: Courttia NewlandCanongate, pound.Review by Barry DidcockAs well as being a novelist, playwright and co-editor of The Penguin Book Of New Black Writing In Britain, Courttia Newland co-wrote two of the five films in Steve McQueenrsquos acclaimed Small Axe anthology, which delved deep into the history of the black British experience in the s and s. Anyone expecting more of the same in A River Called Time can forget it, however: sprawling, ambitious, often thought-provoking and just as often baffling, Newlandrsquos latest novel is as hard to comprehend as it is to forget.Itrsquos set, initially at least, in an alternate London called Dinium on a world called Geb. In a handy timeline, Newland runs through the main historical events in this alternate universe starting with key dates in Egyptian history . Christrsquos le is shortened by  years, and by  AD the Roman emperors are favouring religions based on Kemetian Cosmology. In , a century ahead of schedule, Henry VIII splits with the Roman Kemite Temple and forms an Anglican one then in  therersquos a Flash War in which the original city of Dinium is obliterated.The Dinium of May , when the novel opens, consists of an Outer City and an Inner City which contains The Ark, an apparent sanctuary built in  and to which Outer City residents can movethey qualy . Within The Ark there are Levels, rising to Level Four for the truly blessed and descending five miles down into the ldquoLowers. Citizens sleep in pods which steer and control their dreams. All light is articial.Of course The Ark is a glittering lie. The Levels are split into Zones and in the lowest is the Poor Quarter, whose denizens undertake menial jobs and whose hardscrabble lives are plagued by crime and the authoritarian brutality of the Ersquolul Corporation.Our protagonist is Markriss Denny, or Mark, or Mars or Riss, depending on which of several alternative version of his le wersquore wading through at the time. We first meet him as a child living in the Outer City, mourning the death of his brother and hanging out with his friend, Nesta. He moves to The Ark and becomes a journalist, at least for the first  pages. In the second of the three acts, Markriss, Nesta and Markrissrsquos we Chileshe are now members of The Outsiders, a group of political activists plotting to take on the Ersquolul Corporation.Markriss is subject to visions. At times he leaves his body and moves into an astral plane where he communes with the spirit of Professor Harman Wallace, inventor of the pods. There is much talk of ethereal bodies and of chakras. At one point Markriss lies with ldquoevery hair rising to attention, the subtle atoms formerly at rest above his mortal body awakened, chakras spinning, primed to make a superfluity of connections. So is act one a hallucinatory vision  Does act two take place in an alternate reality, with an alternate Markriss  Is Wallace trickster or guide Act three, the most coherent, takes us to modern-day London where Markriss is writing about his own day-to-day le, real-le events such as the  General Election and also making notes for a long-standing project about The Ark. It ties things together up to a point, though it isnrsquot long before wersquore flipped back into the world of Geb and a coda whichus to the le of Markriss .Class, race, dferent iterations of self, the power of the imagination, Afrofuturism, politics, spirituality, physics and philosophy ndash itrsquos all here in a high-concept novel blending sci-fi and speculative fiction with the self-critique of memoir, though unravelling it confidently on a single read-through of the -plus pages is quite an undertaking.

title: five-arts-venues-cant-wait-revisit-lockdown
story: The absence of live entertainment has hit hard. But so has the absence of art and cinema, particularly outside the cities where they are often the heart and soul of their communities.As we continue to hunker down during the current lockdown wersquove been thinking of the venues we canrsquot wait to revisit later this year.The Hippodrome, BorsquonessSince it was refurbished and reopened in , architect Matthew Steelersquos  cinema ndash the countryrsquos oldest purpose-built picture house ndash has found a new le showing new and classic films. It has also established itself as a key venue for early cinema with its annual Silent Film Festival. Like so many arts venues, it had a dficult year in , but hopefully  will see itto normality. When it reopens and we can all travel again, itrsquos really well worth a visit. To be fair, leg room is a bit tight, but the welcome will be warm. Sight and Sound magazine, no less, said of the Hippodrome, ldquo a cinema could give you a hug this is what it would feel like.Visit hippodromecinemaDCA, DundeeLong before the VA arrived on Dundeersquos waterfront to soak up all the attention, the DCA, along with the nearby Dundee Rep Theatre , has been doing its bit to reinvigorate the cityrsquos image. Offering exhibition space, two cinema screens, a shop and an excellent cafe restaurant, the DCA is always worth a visit. A new exhibition by Japanese artist Chikako Yamashiro is scheduled to open next month. Herersquos hoping.Visit dca.org.ukDunfermline Carnegie Library  Galleries, DunfermlineThe award-winning extension to the Carnegie Library, designed by Richard Murphy Architects, opened in  and has done much to revitalise Dunfermlinersquos town centre, adding gallery space, a museum of local history and the excellent Heaven Scent cafe to the mix. Itrsquos a building worthy of a former Scottish capital.Visit onfeRead More: Five Scottish libraries we lovePerth TheatreVisit horsecrossThe Dick Institute, KilmarnockIf things were normal Grayson Perryrsquos The Vanity of Small Dferences should be opening at the Dick Institute on January . Unfortunately, these are not normal times and who knows when we will next get the chance to visit. Still, the exhibition is a reminder that Kilmarnockrsquos gallery has always been ambitious in its programming. The work of Bill Viola, Abram Games, Quentin Blake, Gerhard Richter, Nathan Coley and Christine Borland have all featured over the years.Visit eastayrshire

title: luckenbooth-evokes-edinburghs-gothic-past-across-nine-creepy-storeys
story: Jenni FaganWilliam Heinemann, pound.Review by Dani GaravelliAT the beginning of Luckenbooth ndash Jenni Faganrsquos much-anticipated third novel ndash Jessie MacRae, daughter of the devil, sails into the Water of Leith in a coffin. Her horns hidden in a tumult of hair, she walks along Constitution Street towards a city that is dark and unheimlich a city populated by beggars, glowering gargoyles and men of the cloth who swoop down the High Street like crows. The year is , but it is an Edinburgh Kidnappedrsquos David Balfour would instantly recognise: a place of hubbub, and of tenements, both multi-storeyed and multi-storied, ldquostanding sentinel around the Tron.In recent years, Edinburgh has plied a trade as a backdrop for the crime novels of Ian Rankin and others. But Fagan plays up the cityrsquos Gothic traits to produce an instant classic. Suffused with dread, Luckenbooth is a perverse love song to its castle and its catacombs its plague victims and its Presbyterianism its hedonism and its haar.The ghost of Robert Louis Stevenson stalks its narrative wynds. Deacon Brodie ndash respectable cabinet maker by day housebreaker by night ndash is the inspiration for Luckenboothrsquos villain Mr Udnam just as he was for Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. Fagan acknowledges the debt. She has Flora ndash a trans woman at a sex party ndash remind us that Stevensonrsquos most famous novel was written during a six-day cocaine binge. And Luckenbooth possesses that same frenetic energy the same fever-dream quality found in her debut, The Panoptican, about a teenage girl in care. It is asall the images in Faganrsquos head are engaged in a breathless, deathless race on to the page. References to Hitler, druids, pagans and the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse snap at each otherrsquos heels. Witches and assassins, madams and mediums jostle for their place in a universe which, while anchored in a familiar geographical literary landscape, moves to its own wild beat.The Luckenbooth of the title ndash No  Luckenbooth to be precise ndash is a nine-storey building in the heart of the Old Town. It is named after the lockable booths for traders ndash luckenbuiths ndash which stood nearby, but a luckenbooth is also a silver brooch sometimes worn to ward off witches. This is ironic because the tenement is cursed. Jessie has been sold as a surrogate mother to wealthy landlord Mr Udnamrsquos baby. The atrocity that follows works its way into the fabric of the building, rising like damp through its floors, infecting its eccentric residents over the course of almost  years.Faganrsquos conjuring of the tenement is an incredible feat. She creates a literary Windows in the West, providing fleeting glimpses of self-contained worlds: a man at his piano a parrot flying round a room. But more than that, she captures the ebb and flow of humanity, the way we weave in and out of each othersrsquo lives, barely touching.There are the daily routines: ldquoA kettle whistle goes on a stove on the fourth floor each day at am, am, pm and then again at pm, Levi, a black American, who works in the Royal Dick veterinary building, writes to his brother in . But there is also a fluidity, an overlapping of existence the living moving in tandem with the dead. Leitmots create connections. Jessie has a cage around her heart made of ldquobone, bone, bone, Levi sorts animal bones ldquonumerically by size and species, and the tenement has access to the vaults where body-snatchers Burke and Hare once wheeled their victimsrsquo bodies.Like all great Gothic works, Luckenbooth deals in duality: good evil, light dark. The more sins Mr Udman commits, the more philanthropic he becomes. Jessie has her fatherrsquos horns, but stands up against the landlord. Flora has changed from male to female, but is still caught in a biological trap. Copious mind-altering drugs are consumed and sex is had in an impressive range of numerical gender combinations.This duality extends to the setting. Fagan builds on the idea of there being two Edinburghs, ldquoone above ground and one below, one in the centre and one on the outskirts. This duality can be thrilling. ldquoSometimes the sky races in such a way it seems there are two skies from two dferent worlds entirely ndash rushing at each other in opposite directions, layers of cloud and dark moodiness, Levi writes.The lust extends to the setting, too. Fagan comes at Edinburgh like a voracious lover, eager to explore both its conspicuous beauty and its secret places. She runs the gamut of its sinister hotspots: Greyfriars Kirkyard, the execution site on the Grassmarket, the notorious Pubic Triangle. But that is not enough. She wants us to see the city from every angle, in every light, so she sends Flora up the Salisbury Crags. At sunset ldquothey look like they are on fire, Flora says. ldquoThe entire thing turns rose gold.From the top she can see the ldquowhole city skyline sparkle before her. Just as in The Sunlight Pilgrims ndash which features a frozen dystopian near-future in the Highlands ndash Faganrsquos writing sparkles most when she is describing landscape. But she also crams Luckenbooth full of legends. She tells of Robert the Brucersquos heart, cut out so it could be taken to the Holy Land, and of Baska Murmanska, the polar bear mascot of a First World War Polish battalion, led through Leith by war-weary soldiers. Now and then, she tries too hard, and the stories begin to stack up like supermarket BOGOFs but mostly her vivid descriptions keep everything fresh.Luckenbooth is a horror story, originally and beautully told. But it is also a paean to the city Hugh MacDiarmid described as a ldquomad Godrsquos dream. This quote is the bookrsquos epigraph, and Fagan serves it well. Indeed, so fully has she fleshed out MacDiarmidrsquos vision, she may have ruined Edinburgh as a location for Gothic novelists for many years to come.

title: susan-calmans-grand-day
story: Susan Calmans Grand Day Out.Like Wallace and Gromit Kind of. But rather than travelling to the moon, the Glasgow-born comedian is making six scenic road trips around Britain.Tell me more.After visiting Cornwall and Devon in the opening episode , this weeks instalment sees Calman head for north-west England and the Lake District in her vintage camper van Helen.:Scot Squad star Manjot Sumal on why he loves Lyle Hill in GreenockHelen Named in honour of Dame Helen Mirren.Ah, of course. And whats the plan Calman begins her -mile journey just south of Penrith, travelling down through the lakes, before heading west to finish near Keswick.Highlights, please.Some eye-wateringly steep roads, not least the formidable Honister Pass. title: gavin-francis-gp-coronavirus
story: To be a GP at the start of the st century was not so very dferent from being a GP in the s or s. ldquoThere was a kind of timeless feeling about the nature of the work, he tells me.And then this time last year everything began to change.Sunday morning. January . It is the day before the latest lockdown is announced and Francis is thinking about our lives under the shadow of the coronavirus about how his le and work has changed in the last  months and how everyone rsquos has too.Francis who is both a GP and an author has written Intensive Care, a book about what it was like to be a doctor in the first few months of a pandemic.In the past he has written about his love of islands , his time spent in Antarcticaand about medicine and human change inthe award-winning Shapeshters. ldquoI make sense of the world through writing about it, he explains.In Intensive Care he charts his experiences in , in both an inner-city GPrsquos practice in Edinburgh and his short time spent as a doctor up on Orkney.The result, as he writes in the introduction, is an attempt at ldquoan eyewitness account of the most intense months I have known in my -year career.Define intense, Gavin  ldquoI was trying to keep my clinic going because Irsquom a GP partner with key colleagues in an inner-city practice. I was trying to manage the home-schooling of my children. I was managing a huge amount of uncertainty and stress among my patients, among my staff and my colleagues.ldquoAnd then, when I actually was seeing covid patients, the kind of measures we had to take were extraordinarily dficult to get used to the layers, the barriers, theof time it took to get all the PPE on and getall off again safely.ldquoIt just put huge pressure on the simple business of medicine, which is to see people in distress and attempt to ease their suffering. It was phenomenally complicated by the measures that we had to take. I suppose thatrsquos what I mean by intense, because everything was just laden with this stress and with this drama brought by the virus.Clearly, things are not getting better. We are entering this new year with coronavirus cases surging. Francis, like he has been for the last  months, is on the front line.ldquoItrsquos very, very dficult. Where Irsquom working in Edinburgh the hospitals arenrsquot full yet, like the scenes we are seeing in the south-east of England, but they are filling up.ldquoTherersquos a winter beds crisis every year, but this year is so much worse because wersquove got this terrible new respiratory virus to deal with on top of everything .There are a few small upsides, he says. There has been a lot less flu around this winter than normal as a result of all our social distancing. Still, last week he got an email from NHS Lothian asking him and his colleague to do everything within their power to try and prevent admitting patients to hospital.Read More: Grief in a time of pandemicThatrsquos an annual request, he says. However, he adds, ldquoWersquore having to contemplate shutting down routine care yet again. Wersquore becoming a national covid service at the moment.To think back to last January and February now is to recall another world. We lived in a pre-pandemic world and it took us all a while to realise how much was changing. As a GP, Francis and his colleagues had to completely rethink how to deliver care, how to organise their daily practice of medicine. It was a tricky transition.ldquoWe were forced into trying to manage things on the phone because we had no option. Ordinarily my training would tell me you should always see people face to face.Francis had a front-seat view of the spread of the virus. In the book he points out that that last February and March he was very quickly aware of how rapidly the virus was spreading, more rapidly than the government, health boards and the chief medical officer seemed to be acknowledging at the time.ldquoI would hear stories that made me conscious of just how widespread the virus was in the city, Francis recalls. ldquoI was working up in Orkney in February before it had really hit and then, by the time we were into March, it was definitely spreading quite quickly when I was back in my usual practice.ldquoThe government knew that, but I think this was such an unprecedented, explosive situation in terms of controlling the infection that at every stage it feels like the government couldnrsquot quite believe that they were going to have to go to these extremes.ldquoThey couldnrsquot quite believe that they were going to have to close down all the hotels, that they were going to have to shut down flights in and out of the city. At every stage, when it proved we had to do these things, there was an understandable and justiable reluctance to go that extra step, which subsequently proved necessary.ldquoAnd thatrsquos why I think every single Western country has struggled with this virus. The ones that have done pretty well with it in the Far East have got populations that are willing to tolerate a far greater level of state intrusion into their lives.ldquoCountries like the UK are not used to accepting that the state can just lock us up in our own houses for  days.ldquoWersquore not used to having to hand over our personal details every time we visit a pub or a restaurant. Wersquore just not used to that level of state intrusion.Intensive Care is a cool, thoughtful book, and not one, it should be said, particularly interested in blame. ldquoNo, not at all. Itrsquos very easy to look back retrospectively. At every stage I was quite incredulous too. lsquoAre they are really going to have to close all the schools  Are they really going to have to ban flights rsquoWhat he hopes is,this happens again, we will be quicker to close borders and quicker to ramp up mass testing.ldquoGoing forward from this pandemic I think government will be a lot better at keeping pandemic stocks of PPE up to date. Ours had all started to go out of date because they had been stockpiled for the swine flu of .ldquoWe did have access to masks, aprons and so on. We didnrsquot have gowns and the WHO were advising people to wear full gowns.One of the most striking revelations in Intensive Care is how quickly Francis and his colleagues were dealing with a surge in mental health problems as lockdown began. ldquoOne day,  March, almost everything I dealt with related to mental health, he writes.Thatrsquos just two days after Boris Johnson announced a lockdown, I say.ldquoIt was happening so fast, partly because I am in in the city centre of Edinburgh and so much of the economy of that part of Scotland is devoted to tourism. Therersquos a lot of guesthouses there, a lot of people who depend on tourists. And suddenly that was all blown away.ldquoSo, I was seeing the effects of people not just coming to terms with a very dangerous, le-threatening pandemic infection, but also the collapse of their businesses, especially at that time when it wasnrsquot clear what the economic support measures would be. There was a real sense of terror among people who were furloughed or even under threat of redundancy. The uncertainty of that, combined with being ordered to stay home on the pain of essentially risking your le.The impact on our mental health led Francis to join a number of doctors and nurses in writing a letter to education secretary John Swinney to try to get children back into schools.ldquoYou could see the government was doing everything it could to avoid a measurable harm, which was covid deaths among adults because that is a statistic that would be on the front of every newspaper. A terrying statistic. But there were innumerable, less measurable harms still being perpetrated.ldquoI donrsquot envy the politicians making these choices, but, essentially, because the deaths were measurable, everything was done to mitigate that. But there were enormous harms being done by keeping the kids off school, by enforcing everybody to stay home, by the shutdown of massive sectors of the economy. Thatrsquos before we get on to the enormous harm done to the elderly people told to shield and to be away from anybody, to not see their grandchildren for month after month after month. And Irsquom seeing real outcomes of that now, after almost a year of this.ldquoPeople in their late eighties and nineties are saying, lsquoYou know, I might not have many years left and to avoid seeing the people who make my le most worthwhile for so long has been truly terrible, truly dficult.rsquoThe impact on our mental health can also be seen in the rise this last  months of cases of self-harm, panic attacks, and psychosis ndash all, Francis says, on the rise in his own practice.Itrsquos a reminder, I suggest, that being human is about contact and without it we are damaged.ldquoAbsolutely and one of the cruellest aspects of this virus is it spreads through touch and through voice. Singing was one of the worst ways of spreading the virus. Wersquore told to mask up to not touch each other. Itrsquos kind of like an attack on the most basic elements of our humanity.Wersquore being urged to resume clapping for our ldquoheroes again. Francis quite enjoyed the clapping that accompanied the early weeks of the lockdown. Not all of his colleagues felt the same, though.ldquoSome of them hated it. I didnrsquot so much like the clapping, but I really liked the opportunity to chat with my neighbours. If I happened to be home on a Thursday evening and all the neighbours were out on the street, it was quite nice to see each other, four metres apart.ldquoAnd itrsquos interesting how much that amazing upwelling of good feeling towards key workers at that time has kind of dissolved now.Well, indeed. He talks about the scenes of covid-deniers gathering outside hospitals in England with utter incomprehension.ldquoWhat can we do to assure people it is absolutely not a hoax  People are dying of this and the ones that arenrsquot dying of it are very ill, sometimes for a long time. Irsquom not sure how  you can convince people. Itrsquos quite extraordinary to me that people can even deny it exists.Does that make you angry  ldquoNot so much angry. Irsquom absolutely mystied.What the pandemic has reminded us, Francis suggests, is that we are vulnerable. But also, of human ingenuity. ldquoThe ability to create several al vaccines within a few months of this emerging is tremendous, he says.ldquoOn the other hand, itrsquos quite startling to think we havenrsquot progressed in terms of how we best manage and control this kind of viral outbreak. I found that depressing in many ways. In some ways we havenrsquot moved on, for all our sophistication.And so here we are in January , somewhere between hope and fear. Francis leans towards the former. ldquoYeah, Irsquom really hopeful. Irsquom optimistic because we have two vaccines approved for use. Irsquove already had my first vaccination. Irsquom getting my booster later this week. Wersquore vaccinating care homes just now. Wersquore going to vaccinate the over-s very shortly.ldquoThat is the only way wersquore going to get out of this. Wersquore going to get herd immunity through vaccination rather than herd immunity through people having caught and recovered from it.ldquoOf course, it could have been better. Of course, I could point to things that have gone wrong over the last year. Now what wersquove got to do is stick with the measures and vaccinate, vaccinate, to get out of it.Gavin Francis is a GP. His job has changed in the last year. He hopes, soon, it willto the rhythm of the past.Intensive Care by Gavin Francis is published by Profile Books in association with Wellcome Collection, priced pound.

title: independence-snp-time-authentic-left-scotland-get-organised
story: In a judicial review the Scottish Creel Fishermenrsquos Federationargued that the decision to reject a proposed pilot no-trawl scheme in the Inner Sound off the Isle of Skye was unlawful. This was owing to the Scottish Government taking account only of opposition to the scheme and did not properly assess the proposal ndash including examining benefits and the wider issues of inshore fisheries management. Lady Poole described Marine Scotland Policy as irrational and their decision as ldquoso unreasonable that no reasonable authority could have come to it.Read more:Itrsquos time for the care sector to be completely nationalisedIf the Scottish Government had any ounce of shame or respect for those "Scottish" values it otherwise purports to foster the Rural Economy Minister, Fergus Ewing, would be handing in his resignation this morning. On his watch Scotlandrsquos seabed has been turned into a ploughed field and our waters, once teeming with a bio-ersity of marine le, have become barren and a Klondyke for Big Fishing.Mr Ewing wonrsquot resign though, because Scottish ministers get to evade responsibility for failure and incompetence unless they are considered sufficiently junior and inconsequential to be thrown overboard. Joe Fitzpatrick discovered this recently when he was made to walk the plank for a decade of failure to address Scotlandrsquos drug crisis.John Swinney, despite a lamentable term as Education Minister, remains intact ndash even after last yearrsquos exams fiasco which exposed a class-based gerrymandering in Scotlandrsquos educational framework which always favours pupils from private schools and those in affluent areas.Lady Poolersquos judgment in favour of the Creelers followed the SNPrsquos rejection late last year of any attempts to curb the rapacious activities of driven grouse moors. These have made vast areas of Scotlandrsquos wild and beautul environment into a theme park for rich people who like to shoot defenceless creatures.No part of Scotlandrsquos natural heritage on land or sea, it seems, is considered too sacred or too importantit can be exchanged for fairytale promises of unspecied jobs of questionable sustainability. Remember those breathless claims of Alex Salmond a decade ago about Scotland becoming ldquothe Saudi Arabia of renewables Thankfully, for the Scottish Government, global and UK forces keep providing opportunities for it to avert our gaze. These also give them space to pivot away from anything radical about what Scotland will look like when it gains its independence.Boris Johnson last week bowled the SNP another gentle delivery to be swept away imperiously by a gleeful Nicola Sturgeon. The UK Prime Ministerrsquos claim that independence would have left Scotland without access to Covid- vaccinations can be set alongside some of Better Togetherrsquos most vivid fictions during the first referendum on independence.Just as ridiculous though, is the Scottish Governmentrsquos claim for billions in Brexit compensation. They know and we know itrsquoll never happen but it eats up valuable column inches that might otherwise be devoted to something more relevant to the real lives of Scots. An over-arching framework of grievance is being constructed here:only Scotland could be part of the EU we could do so many more things at home.Donald Trump and the Capitol Hill mob provided another  for ersionary tactics. When the outgoing President hinted that he might spend time at one of his luxury golf resorts in Scotland rather than attend the inauguration of his successor Joe Biden, Nicola Sturgeon wasted no time in responding. Since then our liberal and media elites have been exulting in a self-indulgent frenzy of sanctimony to explore ways of having his big velvet collar feltever he sets foot in Scotland. In the real world beset by unemployment, drugs deaths and the economic ravages of Covid they care not a jot about this middle-class caprice.Read More:Why the Nativity story belongs in the age of CovidNo matter, it seems, is too trivial for the Scottish Government to strike an unctuous pose. John Swinney tore into Celtic FC for travelling to Dubai for their annual mid-season training camp. No matter that the trip had been organised with the approval of the Scottish Government several months ago and was well within the regulations as they affect elite sports people. The optics didnrsquot look good and this government which governs by optics alone couldnrsquot resist the urge to wag its finger.This is the time when the left-wing of the wider independence movement needs to unite and act as a counter-weight to the influence of big business on the SNP. Wresting control of the partyrsquos ruling NEC from the identity narcissists and designer radicals was a start but this will become meaninglessthey merely participate in the partyrsquos campaign to portray us all as good little Europeans.The vaccination programme will finally draw the sting from this persistent and wily pandemic but it wonrsquot provide a cure for a much greater health apocalypse which will claim many more lives than the Covid. This is what the Scottish Government needs to be about.One of the most effective dissimulations of the elites is that the authentic left are obsessed by ideas of class war. Yet, quietly and implacably, theyrsquove been waging one against the UKrsquos poorest communities. In the next decade this will be observed in how those neighbourhoods will be required to take the biggest hit when the coronavirus account must be settled. The UK Labour Party has effectively removed itself from this struggle with the ascendancy of Sir Keir Starmer, the ultimate establishment plant. In Scotland, the SNP will simply frame all future challenges in alleviating the stress of poverty in terms of being ldquodragged out of Europe against our will.Already, right-wing and neo-liberal ideology is moving to position itself when independence finally comes. The authentic left in Scotland must get organised.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: independence-joanna-cherry-nationalist-view-history-raises-worrying-vision-future
story: What Ms Cherry said was as follows: another referendum is not the only option on independence and thinking that it is reinforces the power of the SNPrsquos adversaries. ldquoOne hundred years ago, she said, ldquoIrish independence came about not as a result of a referendum but as a result of a treaty negotiated between Irish parliamentarians and the British Government after nationalist MPs had won the majority of Irish seats in the  General Election and withdrawn to form a provisional government in Dublin.ldquoWhile no-one wants to replicate the violence that preceded those negotiations, Ms Cherry went on, ldquothe Treaty is in legal and constitutional terms a clear precedent which shows that a constituent part of the UK can leave and become independent by a process of negotiation after a majority of pro-independence MPs win an election in that constituent part.Read more:Five questions to answer in Letrsquos look at all of that in more detail, shall we  Ms Cherry says Irish independence came about as a result of an Irish British treaty after nationalist success in the  election, but that, Irsquom afraid, is an assertion utterly lacking in context. The negotiations that led to the  treaty did not come about directly from the  election, they came about because of the war of independence it was the result not of a peaceful election but of violent action and any attempt to separate the Irish precedent from the violence, which is what Ms Cherry appears to be trying to do, is misleading and wrong.Letrsquos also look at another part of Ms Cherryrsquos commentary. ldquoNo-one wants to replicate the violence that preceded the negotiations, she says, and on the face of it thatrsquos a call for peaceful action. But itrsquos also anti-historical. There wasnrsquot just violence ldquopreceding Irish independence, the violence got worse as independence progressed and developed into years of terrorism. The story of Irish independence is the story of violent ision before, during, and after and there is simply no way of somehow removing or sidelining the violence so it can be used as a peaceful precedent for Scotland.If Ms Cherry needs reminding why Irsquom saying all of this, the recent House of Commons briefing paper, Parliament and Northern Ireland, -, provides useful context. Itrsquos written by the man who wrote this column for many years, David Torrance, and goes through the constitutional history of the island of Ireland in the greatest detail, underlining in the process how long, complex and violent it has been. It also makes the point that a lot of the early history has slipped from public consciousness, which may explain why Ms Cherry feels able to use it as a precedent for Scotland.So why does it all matter  It matters because the SNP is at the point where therersquos an internal battle going on over the best tactics for achieving independence and Ms Cherry is an influential figure in that battle. I would have thought that makes it extra important she gets her history right and thinks carefully about the consequences of using Ireland as a precedent for Scotland. I fear she hasnrsquot done so because of the flaw that runs through so many nationalists.Read more:The Scottish Government is not to blame for the drugs crisisWhat I mean is the idea that it couldnrsquot happen here. Ms Cherry doesnrsquot appear to consider for a minute that the debate in Scotland could ever erupt into violence, but are we sure of that  Many Americans thought the same way before the riots at the Capitol. The SNP MP Steven Bonnar also tweeted recently that ldquowe will fight to the death for our country and I guess your view on whether that sort of comment could ever lead to actual violence will depend on how literal you think Mr Bonnar was being. He said he was joking.I also think anyone who knows anything about the mood in Scotland should be cautious about thinking there could never be violence here in future. Many Scottish nationalists are furious that theyrsquore not getting their own way, but we should also be aware that Scotland has many of the same tensions as Northern Ireland for many of the same reasons: economic, religious, constitutional. The Loyalist bands are stronger and more vocerous in Scotland than ever. And therersquos already been violence. Remember the Glasgow riots in  when the Irish unity march was met by counter-demonstrators  And the arson attack on the Tall Cranes pub in Govan  What makes anyone think that sort of violence could never happen again, or get worse even What Irsquom saying is that the only responsible thing to do here is to make ourselves aware of the historical backdrop before we start suggesting that the answer to Scotlandrsquos future can be found in Irelandrsquos past. Perhaps Ms Cherry should also remember how her party got here in the first place. In her article for The National newspaper, she writes that the SNP is riding high and support for independence is at unprecedented levels, which it is. ldquoWe would never have got this far, she says, ldquohad we hellip not been prepared to be radical and to think outside the box.The obvious implication of Ms Cherryrsquos words is that nationalists need to be radical again and look to apparent alternatives to a referendum, such as Ireland. But the SNP hasnrsquot got here because of radicalism, itrsquos got here because of a wily ability to use every situation to maximise dference and grievance and underline the apparent need for independence ndash in other words, exactly the opposite of radical. Ms Cherry says it is foolish and dangerous to rule out alternatives to a -style referendum. But may I suggest that, from her point of view, it is just as foolish to ignore the reasons why the SNP has reached this historical high.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

story: LOOKING for something decent to watch on TV, Bob Jamieson stumbled upon a Channel  documentary about a train journey from Glasgow to Mallaig.ldquoThatrsquoll do nicely, he thought to himself, especially as it was narrated by respected English actor Bill Nighy.Alas, the eager viewer became irritated when it transpired that the esteemed thespian talked about "Lock" Lomond.He didnrsquot have much luck with Tyndrum, Rannoch Moor or the Trossachs either.Letrsquos hope Nighy is now offered narration duties on a similarly themed Welsh programme. title: Hold Nicola Sturgeon s calls  her favourite TV show is on its way back
story: Now the fictional TV character Birgitte Nyborg, who counts among her super fans one Nicola Sturgeon, First Minister of Scotland, is on her way back with a much anticipated new series of Danish political drama Borgen.Netflix and the Danish Broadcasting Corporation yesterday announced the full cast for the fourth season was now in place, paving the way for filming to begin. The new series will appear on screens next year.Sidse Babett Knudsen, who plays Nyborg, Denmarkrsquos first woman Prime Minister, said: ldquoYou should be careful with what you say, but I have sky-high expectations on this project. Most of all, I look forward to moving back into Birgitte Nyborg. What a privilege to be able to ride the carousel once again with this character that I love so much.: When Nicola met BirgitteMs Knudsen is not alone in her admiration for the series, which ended its run on BBC in . Scotlandrsquos FM called Borgen ldquothe most authentic political drama Irsquove ever watched. One Saturday night when it was on she tweeted: ldquoOk everyone, wheesht ndash itrsquos Borgen time. She told the Radio Times that she may have rewatched the show ldquoonce or twice. Stephen King was a fan, as was the New York Times, which called it ldquoa bleaker, Nordic version of The West Wing.: The TVshows coming your way in When the second series finale was shown as part of the Edinburgh Film Festival in , Ms Sturgeon, then Deputy FM, was among the sold out audience and took part in a QA with the Danish actor afterwards.Ms Sturgeon said she liked Borgen because it showed in Denmark the kind of country Scotland could be ndash a small nation making a big impact.ldquoWhat is nice about Borgen is it portrays this obviously strong, confident, clever and articulate woman, but you also see her human side and the fact she occasionally has self-doubt, which everyone does, she added.: FM confronted on bombshell claimsldquoYou see her vulnerability, the traumas she goes through in her family le and kicking off her high heels at the end of a busy day. All of that, for women in politics, is something you can relate to.Ms Sturgeon laughed off the suggestion that there could be a Borgen-type drama about Holyrood.ldquoWe are all capable of the skullduggery side of politics, but in my experience, and this crosses the political ide, most politicians are decent people in it for the right reasons.
